importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the lawsuit filing and key events in the political dispute involving Mike Johnson and Adelita Grijalva's swearing-in.
The date when Adelita Grijalva won her congressional election, which triggered the dispute over her swearing-in.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period between Grijalva's election and the lawsuit filing, during which Johnson delayed her swearing-in, raising constitutional and procedural concerns.

keyTakeAways: Arizona’s attorney general, Kris Mayes, filed a lawsuit against the U.S. House of Representatives over Speaker Mike Johnson’s refusal to swear in newly elected Democratic congresswoman Adelita Grijalva.

The lawsuit argues that the Constitution requires elected members to be sworn in upon meeting qualification standards, and that the Speaker does not have the authority to unilaterally delay the swearing-in process.
Johnson claims he is following the precedent set by former Speaker Nancy Pelosi, who delayed seating newly elected members during recess periods.
The lawsuit alleges that Johnson’s refusal is politically motivated, aimed at delaying a petition on Jeffrey Epstein records and strengthening his position in budget negotiations.
Grijalva has not spoken to Johnson in 28 days since winning her election and is attempting to schedule a meeting to resolve the standoff.
The case raises significant questions about the separation of powers, the role of the Speaker in governance, and the constitutional obligation to seat duly elected representatives.
The lawsuit requests a court order allowing a qualified official to administer the oath to Grijalva if Johnson refuses to do so.

namedEntities.name: Kris Mayes
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is the lead legal figure filing the lawsuit, asserting that the Constitution mandates the seating of duly elected officials and challenging Speaker Johnson’s procedural decisions.

namedEntities.name: Mike Johnson
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is the central political figure refusing to swear in Grijalva, citing precedent and asserting control over the House’s session schedule.

namedEntities.name: Adelita Grijalva
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Newly Elected Democratic Congresswoman from Arizona
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Her election and the subsequent refusal to seat her represent a direct conflict over democratic legitimacy and procedural rights in Congress.

namedEntities.name: Nancy Pelosi
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is referenced as a precedent for delaying swearing-in during recess, which Johnson claims justifies his own position.

namedEntities.name: Jeffrey Epstein
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Controversial figure associated with a petition in the House
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The lawsuit claims Johnson’s delay is intended to block a petition related to Epstein’s records, suggesting political motivation.

namedEntities.name: U.S. House of Representatives
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The venue of the lawsuit and the institution where the constitutional dispute over seating a member occurs.

namedEntities.name: Washington, D.C.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The location where the lawsuit is being filed in federal court.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Arizona’s attorney general, Kris Mayes, has sued the U.S. House of Representatives over Speaker Mike Johnson’s refusal to swear in newly elected Democratic congresswoman Adelita Grijalva, who won her seat in late September. The lawsuit argues that the Constitution mandates that all duly elected members must be sworn in, and that the Speaker has no constitutional authority to delay the process. Johnson claims he is following the precedent set by former Speaker Nancy Pelosi, asserting that members elected during a recess should be seated after the House returns to session. However, the lawsuit alleges that Johnson’s delay is politically motivated, aimed at blocking a petition on Jeffrey Epstein records and advancing budget negotiations. Despite having no dispute over Grijalva’s qualifications, Johnson has refused to administer the oath, with Mayes arguing that the Speaker is arbitrarily withholding the right to serve. The case raises constitutional and democratic concerns about the legitimacy of elected representatives and the balance of power within Congress.
title: Arizona Sues Over Mike Johnson’s Refusal to Swear in Democrats’ Newest Congresswoman
